text: 12oz bottle thanks to Eric. Pours out a dark brown topped with a tan head. Nose is light roast pit fruit rich malts some nutty wood. Taste is more of the nice grain and touch of spice.
good looking beer.. brown/amber color, small foamy head. Smell is pretty malt heavy and sweet. Taste is quite sweet, yet smooth... could be a little more carbonated. This is not bad, but not great.

Deep amber beer with a medium foamy khaki head. Nose of candied nuts, dough, and light caramel. Flavor is quite a bit stronger with caramel malt, brown bread, and almonds finishing with a pronounced astringent bitterness. Flavorful beer.

Beer of the Month Club selection. Clear amber with a small but solid head and spotty lace. Aromas of tea, toast, toffee and hints of leather and floral hops. Caramel malts and toffee sweetness up front offset by a hop kick that adds some bitterness. Medium body and carbonation, sticky oily mouthfeel and a sweet finish.
Pours clear light brown, big beige head. Earthy, licorice aroma. Taste is caramel, hay, spicy, hops. Surprisingly light mouthfeel, but creamy.

12 oz. bb Feb 22, 2017. Clear shiny copper-amber with nice legs supporting a thin film of foam. Mild nose has some rich caramel, light toast and a hint of apple. Flavor is toffee turning to a bit of apple and citrus, then a long wood and cardboard finish. Medium-heavy body has a pleasant low-medium carbonation and shows a bit of the abv.
bread, hay, toast, earthy, amber, brown, clear, minimal head, white foam, medium bitterness, full body, creamy, average carbonation, bitter,
It pours reddish brown with an off-white head. The aroma is hops and bread. The taste is earthy hops, bread, and tea. Its got nice bitterness with some sweetness. This is good.
Love the winter warm as being the big strong English ale without the need for all the mulling spices.
Bottle from Liquor Barn. Aroma of malt with a dry hop finish. Taste was a good mix of sweet and bitter.
Has a real full bodied taste to it. A really nice winter beer that goes well with the season.
Balanced overall.. Malty and nutty with some sweetness. Tempered with a good dose of hops that is not very bitter, but still very present. An interesting and very drinkable beer.

Bottle:
Clear copper with a sudsy beige head.
Smoky caramel, pine aroma.
Flavour is toasty caramel malt, tea, grassy bitter.
Really malty......finishes dry.
Very good.
12 ounce bottle. Caramel color. Sticky and sweet with caramel and some floral notes.
Pours a clear, nice-looking red-amber with a healthy khaki head. Fruity nose. Ample esters in the flavor profile. Solid esb.

Sweet caramel aroma with touches of dried fruit and hops. Pours dark with moderate foam. Hops are more present in the taste and balance the sweetness of the malt. Medium body with soft carbonation. The finish is pleasantly clean and dry.
Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass. The appearance is a clear amber with a small white head. The aroma is malt. The taste is malt with some hops. Ayyyyy really like this beer (had to do it)

Poured from the bottle to a tulip. Cloudy mahogany. Thin wispy head didnt stick around. Nose is toffee caramel. The palate is all about the grain bill. Nice balancing with the hops carrying the load through the middle keeping the malts from bogging down the experience. Nice clean finish leaves a little warmth in the throat, doing its job as a winter warmer.
Poured from bottle amber hue with a thin beige head. Aromas of caramel malt and light grass. Taste is sweet caramel alcohol spice and a balanced finish.
Pours a clear orangish light reddish color with ivory colored head. Caramel, malts, and some light grass on the nose; follows onto the palate. Medium bodied. Finishes with mostly malt.
On tap at Bethesda Food and Beverage. Nice copper body with tan head. Nose is malty, toasty and caramel. Taste also caramel and malts. Well-balanced with a warming finish. Yum!

Bottle pour into nonic pint glass from One Stop Market, Haverhill, MA. Aroma is caramel, vanilla, bread, dough. Appearance is beautiful, clear amber with no sparkle, finger-width off-white foamy head with poor retention and leggy lacing. Taste is moderately sweet with alcohol thats a little bit astringent, then caramel end. Palate is medium bodied with average texture, lively late carbonation at tip of tongue and crisp slightly bitter finish. Overall, very true to style--straightforward maltiness.

Bottle. Copper. Earthy hops with toffee, raisin, and caramel. A nice hoppy winter warmer with great balance. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle to a pint. Copper orange with white head. Nice toasted bread and sweet honey with winter spice. Balanced warm finish...

Bottle into tulip. Dark ruby Amber. Not much aroma. Some hints of bread and yeast. Taste is a bit spicy from the hop, dry. Not a lot of malt flavor. Metallic aftertaste which is off putting. Some dried fruit notes. Meh. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: bread, raisin, woody, earthy
Appearance: clear amber, tan head
Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: medium body, sticky, soft carbonation, long finish, 

Delicious

Pours reddish copper with a one finger tan head which fades to very little lacing. Aroma is of toasted bready malts, sweet malts, caramel, dark fruits, toffee, brown sugar, and some light booze. Taste is about the as the aroma with the addition of some light pine and spicy hops. Has a medium body with a semi-creamy mouthfeel and a mostly sweet, long finish. Overall, a pretty nice winter warmer.
Tap @ Jack Browns. Caramel color and aroma., lighter and hoppier than I thought it would be. Not bad.
Some hint of spice here. Light vegetable aroma. Some sweet malt. Pours cloudy amber with OK head. Light sweet finish. Cask at Churchkey.
4 oz pour on draft at Spacebar. Clear dark amber with off-white head. Aromas of toast, biscuit, light citrus. Tastes of woody notes, citrus, toast, biscuit. Medium-light body with a dry finish.

bottle @ Party Town / Florence KY --- Clear dark amber color, two finger beige head, broken curtain of lace. Aroma of malt. Taste is bracing malt that stays big through a carbonated swallow, moving to a spicy, hoppy finish. Solid brew, but also heavy and off-balance.
Light brown with some lacing. Burbon with malt aroma. Malty, Burbon taste with a kick of alcohol.

Bottle to snifter,small off white diminishing head with sparce lacing copper ruby in color. Average roasted aroma. Thin medium light body, average carbonation with a short bitter finish. Rather an unimpressive beer.

12 Fl. Oz. Bottle from Liquor Depot of Dover (Dover, DE). Poured cloudy, amber in color with a small beige head and some spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma is malty and bready, combined with some dark fruit notes. Taste is malty, some bitter notes and some booze in there too. Not bad enjoyable beer.
Appearance is amber with small white head. Aroma is a bit lacking punch. Taste is bitter hops with a slight amount of alcohol. Overall not the best winter ale out there.

Very solid, one of the best ESBs out there for taste and the higher alcohol doesnt really come through that much. Its got the pleasant hop bitterness, not insanely citrusy. The best Heavy Seas Ive had and available in 6-packs, definitely worth it.
Drank this on our trip to St. Michaels. Copper pour. Its malty, generally clean flavors. Not a lot to it, but its good.
deep amber-red color; bready, slightly fruity aroma; bitter with piney hop notes up front with a caramally malty, sem-sweet malty finish

Very nice local to baltimore winter ale. Easy to drink and perfect for a cold night.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from 12 oz bottle. Appearance is caramel brown with gold highlights. Aroma is bready, with caramel and molasses hints. Taste is very malty, with a strong cinnamon flavor, with supporting caramel and molasses and nutmeg. Overall very good, went well with stew.
A relatively well balanced ESB, hoppy and malty with a good mouthfeel. Good winter seasonal
Tap at station on nitro. pour is copper color with tan head. aroma of spice and malt. taste is same. nice spice note and a slight sweet malt backbone.

Draft at the brewery. Pours clear copper brown with a fizzy bubbly white head. Tastes like dry bitter pine hops, with sweet grapefruit, doughy malt, sweet candied grapefruit. Light/medium body and low carbonation. Smells like sweet doughy malt and grapefruit hops.

Bottle from Village Wine and Spirits. Large caramel nose, dark fruit, sugar, all a bit harsh and fumey. Pretty reddish/brown color. Harsh caramel initial, roast malt, sugary, and overly rich fruit. Medium body. Lots of flavor, but mostly rude.

Bottle from old backlog notes. Pours a clear orange amber color with a small beige head. The aroma and flavor have toasted bready malts, mild sweetness, caramel, floral, mild pine resin, moderate bitterness, decent enough.

12 oz bottle into an English pint. The pour is a clear darker ruby or garnet color, with a thin, finger-high, off white head and a decent amount of spotty lace left behind. The aroma is strong on a caramel malt and a good bitterness to it. There is a nice resonating dark fruit dominance on the back end, and its not overwhelming, but its solid. The flavor is a bitter blast up front, but transitions nicely through a good sweet malt and a solid caramel finish. The dark fruits arent really present here in the taste, but the bitterness makes up for it. The mouth feel is a little thin, but there is a nice carbonation and a good dry lingering aftertaste thats quite bitter. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft sample. Pours a light cola brown with a moderate head. Little hop aroma, some doughy bread on the nose. Smooth taste with your typical bitter ESB aftertaste. Pretty decent.
bottle. Amber with one finger head. Smooth malty base with caramel and nut. Moderate English hops balance the flavor profile. Excellent ESB.

Bottle. Aroma has notes of caramel, nuts, toasted malts and bittering hops. Dark amber hue with an average foamy head that mostly diminished and left no lace. Flavor is very sweet and bitter. Palate is full bodied and watery with an average carbonation. Overall an okay brew.

Look what I found buried in the fridge! 12 oz bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours a clear chestnut color. Theres about two fingers worth of pale yellow head, featuring a soft texture and good retention. As it fades, some lacing is left behind.

S: It smells...like an ESB. The malt profile here is quite nutty, with just a hint of chocolate; and even for an old bottle, there is a bit of a hoppy kiss. Earthy hops, in this case. Theres also something funky I cant put my finger on. It doesnt really excite me, even for an ESB.

T: At first, the malts come through with some nutty, fruity, and even (occasionally chocolaty) notes. The malt backbone works decently considering I dont like the maltiness of this style. Before I know it, a wave of generic hop bitterness closes this one. The only hop flavor I really note is a touch of ginger. I actually dont mind this one having generic bitterness, because ESB. Its the jarring transition between the malt and the hops that gets me.

M: Creamy and soft, yet dry on the back end. Its pleasantly carbonated, as well. No real trouble with the mouthfeel - its more of the flavors that support the feel that raises my indifference.

O: Its nice to have your expectations met. Before reviewing this, I thought "meh, ESB"; and after finishing this, I thought "meh, ESB." I didnt particularly enjoy this one, but thats due to my dislike of the style.

pours amber/ruby with a medium white head. aroma has mild fruity notes...berry...malty with subtle chocolate and fruitcake notes. flavor has some doughy notes and fruity...fruitcake for sure...light caramel and chocolate sneak in...some earthy bitterness. mouthfeel is medium/full and the finish is earthy/chocolatey and bitter.

Draft to taster (from notes). Looks good for an Imperial ESB; a transparent copper with foamy head somewhere between off-white and light beige. Smells yeasty, grainy, and mildly hoppy. Tastes like it smells with some toastiness too. Average on the palate. Alright.

Pours a hazy darker amber with a thinner khaki head that settles to a ring and leaves some splotchy, hanging lace. Nose involves brown sugar, some earthy and spicy noble hops, savory doughy yeast, some toffee, mild dark fruit, some toasted malt, some cellared quality. Fairly sweet, pretty bitter. Medium to full bodied, oily, fair carb, with a drying bitter finish. Not enjoying this as much as i hoped. It has some clashing elements, aromatics that compete for attention along with a kind of muddled palate. Not crisp and bright like a standard ESB.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a nonic pint glass. It had a best before date of March 2014 and cost $2.89 ($0.24 per ounce).

Appearance: Dull copper hue with some visible carbonation. Pours to a large, white, frothy head which laces and retains extremely well.

Smell: Virtually odorless. Hint of sweet malt. Thats about it.

Taste: Heavy Seas Winter Storm is described as an "Imperial ESB," which would seem to be a contradiction in terms. While I dont claim to be an expert on the style, I do know what it should taste like and I dont think this is it. The beer is a strange concoction of malt flavor and strong hop presence. Its not that the flavors are bad, its just that they dont seem to match up.

Much like the aroma, the malt presence here is quite faint. Slightly rustic, slightly spicy character with a hint of cinnamon, some confectionery notes and a touch of dark fruit. While thats somewhat enjoyable, theres a strong hoppy character that overshadows it. Dank, earthy, spicy hops are strong from beginning to end. They dont seem to have genuine flavor, but are just there for spice. The problem is there isnt enough base beer to support this much hop character. At no point is it off-putting, but at no point is it particularly enjoyable. 

Drinkability: I was surprised by the low drinkability of this beer. While Heavy Seas Winter Storm is not all that complex, its definitely robust as the bitterness (and some alcohol) really make themselves known. I found myself drinking it in short sips. The mouthfeel is medium, and not all that smooth. It leaves a dry, bitter aftertaste. At 7.5% ABV there should be much more flavor here than there is. Thankfully, that alcohol is not too intense, though there is minor warmth to be felt.

Pours a nice medium amber with red hue that has a nice head that laces and retains well. Nice light nose of biscuit malt with a touch of hops. Medium bodied with good carbonation. A nice balanced flavor of caramel malt sweetness and bitterness against a mild hop flavor, which I believe is East Kent Goldings. Finishes clean with malt sweetness followed by the bitters. My first sampling of Heavy Seas products, and this one outstanding. A nice change of pace for winter warmers that is expertly done.
12/1/2009. From bottle labeled as Category 5. Pours red-brown to copper color with a tan head. Big malty aromas with hints of caramel and hops. Earthy flavors with caramel and hops.

Deep oaky color, creamy tan head, aroma if oats, alcohol, raisin, smoke. Creamy mouth feel, apples and barley. Small hops flavor with bitter finish. Finish is similar to grapefruit juice; lingers a few minutes.
Draft at Gillys in Rockville, MD. Decent dark amber color with an OK foam. Good bitter flavor. Finishes a bit chalky for me.

On tap at the Padonia Ale House. Pours a real dark brown. Small tan head. Nice hop taste while not being the main focus of this brew. The malts take over to give a nice smooth finish. A little bitter. Real good beer
UPDATED: JUL 18, 2015 Nice looking and nice tasting. I like the mix of hint of hops and grain, flowing with smooth malt. Very good balance of flavors, this is one I will buy again soon.
Fantastic bitter beer, one of those thats better than the beer its based on. Malty but balanced, it definitely seems more and more drinkable as temperatures cool.
Bottle->SA. Bright amber with medium offwhite head. A: caramel malt, nuts, earth. T: same, with toffee, bittersweet aftertaste. Pretty good.
Butter aftertaste, but deep and interesting. Can imagine drinking this during a winter storm

Tap at Rattle n Hum way back when - NYC. Pours clear brown with a fine, off-white foam head. Lots of rich malts in here, caramel, ripe fruits, bread, modest earthy bitterness. Full bodied with fine to average carbonation. Sweet and lightly warming to finish, further hefty malts, toasted caramel. Decent.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with very little head. Aroma of caramel. Taste of bitterness and alcohol.

Bottle. Barak BBOTM. Ruby red, cloudy, minimal white head. Biscuit, jam, cherry and candy and wet mud aroma, very alcoholic and slightly bitter taste. Full body, smooth texture, light carbonation and alcoholic finish.

Clear Mahogany with a off-white head. Aroma of berry, molasses, dark caramel, some tartness. Taste of alcohol and heavy malts, burnt sugar, bitterness, full mouth feel, mid palate alcoholic again and tapering to a bitter but sweet ending.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2013 Bottle shared with Ariel at Beer Market Jaffa. Better Beer Of The Month Club. Clear amber. Aroma of malt, caramel, biscuity notes and dusty and earthy hops. Sweet malty flavor with caramel and earthy and slightly citric hops bitterness. Medium-bodied. Solid.

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, best before April 2013.  Pours slightly hazy ruby red color with a 1 finger fairly dense cream colored head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers.  Spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass.  Aromas of raisin, pear, caramel, toast, brown bread, floral, light pepper, light toffee, and toasted earthiness.  Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance and complexity of malt notes; with solid strength.  Taste of raisin, pear, caramel, toffee, toast, brown bread, floral, pepper, pine, light nuttiness, and earthy spiciness.  Good amount of spicy pine bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of light fruits, caramel, toffee, toast, brown bread, floral, pepper, pine, and earthy spiciness on the finish for a good bit.  Very nice balance and complexity of malt and fruity ester flavors; with a good hop balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish.  Medium carbonation and medium-full body; with a creamy and lightly sticky mouthfeel that is good.  Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a very nice imperial ESB style.  Nice complexity of malt/fruity notes with hop balance; and quite smooth to sip on.  A very enjoyable offering.
BBOTMC, Pours deep red with a nice beige head, aroma of tangerine and strawberries, flavor is bitter and pretty dry, with some floral tones, alcohol and cookies, medium bodied+, nice

12oz bottle poured into a tumbler glass.
Clear brown color with some deep copper hues, small beige head.
Nutty aroma, with caramel, grassy hops and some earth.
Sweet dark caramel flavors, toffee, nuts, medium bitterness and warming alcohol.
Low carbonation, med-full body, rich but a bit too strong. Cool.

Bottle: pours a nice dark brown color with a medium off white head.  Bready, malty sweet aroma, some floral hoppiness going on.  The flavor is sweet, but still finishes with a slight bitter taste.  Nice winter beer, something different than most winter ales.
UPDATED: APR 1, 2013 From a bottle, aroma is floral and pine, taste is smooth with a nice bitter kick. Very enjoyable
Nice dark brown coloured beer with a decent sized head. Taste includes a little bit of caramel. Very nice beer for winter days!

Bottle.  Pours  a dark redish brown.  Small off white head.  Malty aroma.  Rich mild bitter flavor with some roast and caramel.  Mild bitter in the mouthfeel.  ESBs arent my favorite style, but I really respect this one.  Definitely would drink again.

Best before February 2013.
Appearance: The body is clear and copper to mahogany, the head si dense with a light tan color, decent retention and leaves a thin coating and a creamy ring.
Aroma: The aroma is malty with caramel and some dark fruits, a light earthy hop profile is hidden in the malts.
Taste: The hops are much more pronounced here cutting through the sweet malts providing a slightly floral and earthy perhaps a touch spicy, hop profile with a moderate bitterness. The malts are sweet, toasted caramel and figs come to mind, that balance the hops nicely.
Palate: Medium bodied, moderate carbonation.
Overall: This is decent, but I cant say that anything about it makes me want to try it again.

12oz bottle---> wine glass.  Pours a deep brownish amber with very little head and little lace.  Smells of bready molasses and mild pine.  Taste is burnt caramel and nice piney hops and slight licorice.  Medium-thick palate with very little carbonation.  Not a favorite style of mine, but this is a fairly well done beer.
Nice dark amber/brown with thin beige head; flavor is roasty nutty notes followed by bitter tanginess; feeels very thick with slight foaminess; aroma is malty more than anything.  I like this beer.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle with March 2013 clipped off the label. It pours out like a winter storm at sea with swirling carbonation bubbles circling around and becoming a dark amber reddish tone with a modest off-white head. Delightful to look at. The aroma is of dark malts, toffee, and plum with a played down hop note. The body is smooth and bold.  The taste is right where it should be for an English Strong with moderate sweetness at first and a low to moderate bitterness winding things down

Poured from 12 oz. bottle.

Clear, dark orange-brown with 2-finger cream-colored head and excellent lacing.

Aroma of bread, grain and herbal hops.

Taste of dark bread, molasses, citrus and roasted coffee.

Medium/full body and medium/high carbonation. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle. Copper color topped by a medium-sized creamy beige head. Aroma is toasted malt with notes of burnt sugar and earthy, grassy hops. Flavor is toasted malt with hints of toffee and spicy hops. Some dryish, peppery hops in finish.

Draft. Amber color, decent white head. Creamy almost slick body, mild malt aroma, some bite in the taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12 oz. Bottle. Nice, malty scent of bready sweet roll with some hop, pininess. Medium body, frothy feel. Hops, bitter, bready sweet roll, touch of caramel finish. Not too shabby.

Bottle. Reddish brown and clear pour with a finger thick Off white head. Bread, chestnut, caramel. Surprisingly bigger than expected body with syrupy bitter and brandy-like finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Mainly caramel malt for aroma, a touch of pine and spice. Brownish orange, transparent and still. Surprise bitter start, long baked cookie dough finish. Mid-to-heavy body, the high content does shine through. Not the usual English style strong beer: too bitter and not sticky enough.

Pours a slightly hazy chestnut color with some ivory head.  There is too much brown for me to call it an amber.  Aroma is mainly caramel malt with some breadiness.  Taste is malty and bready with a little spice and bitterness mixed in. Body is medium.  Not a bad beer but not what I would consider an ESB.  It is too sweet.

Bottle. Rich buttery caramel malt aroma with just a hint of hops.  Chestnut with a moderate ivory head. Caramel malt, harsh weedy hops, a little alcohol flavor. Medium to full sticky body, moderate carbonation. The weedy hops ruined this one for me.  It just wasnt a pleasant type of hops flavor. I was a bit surprised at the bitterness considering I didnt get much hops in the nose.

Draft. Poured a deep amber with a slightly thicker than thin tan head with good lacing. Aroma had a great balance between the malts and hops and the flavor was the same way. Nice bitterness on the back end. A great take on a winter warmer going the ESB route. Nicely done.
Bright, fresh aroma. Deep mahogany color. Hoppier than anticipated. Evergreen notes. Well rounded, medium bodied.
On draft at whole foods. Pours a cloudy caramel color with a creamy off white head. Malty aroma and flavor.
Draft at Tuskies. Pours brown with a thin khaki head. Slight malt sweetness on the nose. Taste is a bit more hop forward than I expected. Hides its alcohol well. Solid but not a fave.

12oz bottle - worst pour ever or just the headiest beer ever. Pours amber with creamy off white head and great lacing. Metallic caramel and grass. Fairly malty but thin. Dangerous. I bet this gets better at room temp. Fairly balanced taste wise.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2012 Draft at Khyber Pass and again at Sugars. Poured a slightly hazy red amber brown with a frothy white head. Bitter malts. Like a slightly sweet molasses tea made with a piece of burnt wood. Coffee notes as it warms. Higher ABV kicks in at the end. Pumped up ESB but seems lacking in character beyond a few notes.

It pours a clear amber with a thin white head that fades into lacing.  The aroma is a soft blend of malt and hops.  The taste is similar.  Theres a nice malty character upfront followed by bitterness in the finish.  Its clean and fairly smooth for the 7.5%.  The lingering bitterness makes it somewhat difficult to drink this beer fast or in mass quantity but its not bad overall.
tap. hazy amber, oily cream island with collar head. Extremely medicinal nose is bark, light bile and plum. Ultra sugary flavor burns throat, light spice and fruit. Sticky body. Too strong.

Poured a clear amber with a big light tan head. Aroma is caramel, nuts, floral, cereal, pine, and cereal. Taste is floral, caramel, citrus, toast, raisin, and grass. Finish is bitter and long lasting with a touch of alcohol burn.
Bottle. Pours a clear and dark brown color with a moderate head. Strong malty bits to the nose. Taste is a little roasty, and just a tad bitter. Nice strong winter beer.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2012 Draft at the Heavy Seas Brewery.  Dark amber brown with off-white head in a pint glass.  Aroma is bread, caramel malt, spices and citrus hops.  Taste starts out sweet and ends bitter.  A little alcohol heavy but in a good way.  Palate is sticky with medium mouth-feel.  Started out different but grew on me with more sips.  Now I need more!

Pours a deep brown amber a great, cream colored creamy head that sticks around. Aroma is pretty sweet with some earthy hops presence, light toasted nose, some sweet caramel and  fruity apple and cherry flavors. Flavor starts off with a very smooth toasted, caramel malt flavor with some notes of light chocolate mixed in followed up by a very strong fruity apple flavor with a strong earthy hops bitterness and warm alcohol nip at the end. Body is very dense with low fine carbonation making it feel creamy as you drink it. Alcohol is just a touch strong as it can be a bit overpowering at the end. Overall a pretty good beer with a well balanced malty sweetness.
Pours a mahogany color. Smell is of hops, floral. Taste is well balanced hops and malts, a touch sweet, a bit of alcohol. Overall an enjoyable beer.
bottle - Pours dark amber with a tan head. It has a rich caramel malt aroma and flavor with moderate bitterness that balances the caramel malt well. Its a good, straightforward, full bodied brew.

Originally reviewed: 11/24/08. Pours a deep ruby with barely any amount of head. Little spotty lacing. Smells of citrus and malt. Some slight alcohol scent wafting out. 

Taste of alcohol and some citrus notes. Deep bitter aftertaste. Some licorice and dark fruit flavors. Gets better as it warms. Not too bad. Moutfeel is nice and crisp due to a decent amount of carbonation. Not a bad ESB. But wouldnt drink a ton of these due to the ABV.

Pours a nice red amber. Light aroma of amber malts and a little hops. Medium bodied with a bitter palate.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A very good winter warmer beer, nice and malty with a very good finish of hop flavor. Nice and high in alchol which keeps you warm on a cold night.

Bottle.  Different label than that in the picture.  Purchase before:  03/12.  Pours a ruby/amber color with a nicely sized beige head.  An aroma of caramel maltiness, toffee, some cereal, a doughy yeastiness, and the slightest hint of citrus in the background.  A relatively medium-bodied palate.  Caramel, toffee, and a dusting of brown sugar upfront taste-wise.  A lightly biscuity middle.  Kinda bready.  An ample amount of bittering grassy hoppiness at the end.  Some nice spiciness all the way through.  The alcohol is hidden very well.  Easy to drink and quite pleasant.

On tap at Oceans & Ale in Williamsburg, VA. Copper in color with a decent off-white head. Aroma is of bread dough, caramel, citrus and spicy hops. Taste is of toast, toffee, and citrus with a wonderful hop finish.

I liked this definitely a good example of a winter warmer.  Slight hops but not really much mostly malty. Carmel notes and a good bit of sugar dominate the body that linger through the finish. Good winter beer.
Bottle.  Aroma has malt in the forefront and dominates the flavor with big bitterness at the end.  This was a bit much for me and not my favorite style.

Bottle. A clear brown beer with good head retention and lacing.  Aroma is full and fresh sweet malty ripe dark fruit with a bit of butter.  Some pine and funky NW hops are in there as well.  Flavor is sweet malty at first but dries quickly to a long bitter finish. Slick and sticky palate.  Pretty well constructed.  Nothing I love about any individual element but it works together.

12oz bottle.  Pours clear copper with thick off-white head; good lacing.  Aroma is floral and citrus hops, spice, caramel, and toasted malt. Flavor is initially hoppy and bitter (floral and grapefruit tastes) which is then balanced out by sweet malt (bread and slight caramel) notes.  Medium body and carbonation.

Bottle.  Pours a clear dark amber body with a small fizzy beige head that left some nice lacing.  The nose is a balance between toasted malts and a floral hoppiness, leaning towards the malty side.  Certainly malt leaning on the flavor, but finishes with a moderate spicy hop note and some lingering bitterness.  The more I have the more the underlying sweetness emerges and gets a little tiring.  Medium bodied, a bit clingy, with fizzy forced carbonation.  Not bad at first, but I quickly got bored with it.

This is a full bodied and full-flavored beer. There is a generous and balanced helping of both hops and malts, a changing fruitiness, and sutle spices. Seems to be approaching flavors similar to a barleywine. Very good.
This was a very good winter warmer, and I will make it a yearly ritual to have some of these stashed away for those cold winter nights.

Had on cask at Nicholsons in Cincinnati.

Arrived a clear ruby with a small head. Excellent lacing.

The smell was full of floral/citrus hops. Some caramel malt as well.

The flavor is very hop forward. Wonderful citrusy hops dominate throughout with a quite assertive bitterness. Malt notes come in at the end and linger.

This is a great beer and one that I am thrilled I got to try on cask. Will definitely seek out again.
Tap - Big foamy head, medium copper color, mild malt aroma, nice balanced flavor - nothing outstanding, but not bad

12oz pours a dark amber color. little off white head, aroma of sweet malt characterstics. almost has a touch of a fruity flavor think its based on the sweetness of the malt. decent enough not a huge fan of esb. but this beer is pretty much spot on for enjoyment.

On the sixth day of Christmas 2011.  Pours amber brown with a creamy tan head.  Aroma is caramel, earthyness and citrus.  Taste is sweet with bitters on the finish.  Medium mouthfeel with a drying finish.  Alcohol lends slight warming.

Heavy Seas Winter Storm Category 5 Ale is a crystal clear and very sparkling copper ale with a huge, foamy, off white head that has outstanding retention.  A sweet grainy bready raisin aroma is kind if muffled by the head.  The soft, smooth, full body has a bone dry finish.  Its creamy.  A spicy bitterness is at the front, first like juniper and then like wood resin.  Theres a slight baklava sweetness lingering, but the bitterness keeps it opressed.  This is a big burly beer. Good stuff.
12oz bottle. Not my favorite winter brew, but not bad at all! Dirty malty color to the pour. Very spicy aroma, with a bit of a hop finish. Ill be trying this one again!

12oz bottle. Clear lighter brown with a small off-white head. Fruity, perfumey alcohol, lighter spicy and floral hops, and some toasty carmel malt in the aroma. The flavor has noticeable alcohol which is almost floral and a light malty sweetness but pretty good balance overall. Finishes with a medium bitterness. Medium bodied with average carbonation. A little too much alcohol presence for me, but a nice beer other than that.

Appearance: lightly hazed reddish brown with a one-finger off-white head slowly shrinking to a thick cap, with pretty lace.   Aroma: toasted oat bread, with strong notes of dank, earthy hops with a bit of citrus hidden underneath.   Taste: caramel and toasted malts over a solid wet-leaf hop profile.   Finish: medium length, a little dry, with a good balance of toasty malts and bitter hops.   Notes: A very balanced and drinkable beer for a 7.5 abv.  Alcohol extremely well hidden.  Overall, pretty nice but also pretty average.

Mostly clear, deep dark red color, minimal off-white head, some lace. Good spicy bitter taste, with a light sweetness. Very tasty. Some toastiness to the grains here, and the hops come at you in a quick blast. A very balanced beer. Or at least balanced around the center I prefer my brews to be.. Big, a good a good amount of hops, with an even toasty-malty sweetness, that is. Carbonation is a bit sharp, however, and theres a slight oiliness, but otherwise the mouthfeel is good.
Sweet caramel taste with a slight hop bite. clear amber pour with a weak head. Decent beer.

Poors a dirty brownish gold with a large foam head that is a off white color.  Appears to be unfiltered. Smells of sweets hops, like its loaded with them. There is also some citrus in the smells as well. Taste is a well balanced mix of malt and hop. These are the commanding elements but other aspects such as toffee and caramel kind of add to the malt. Mostly this just taste like a bitter ale. Its good a good winter warmer type of beer I feel the 7.5%abv in my chest and not in my mouth. Dry malty finish, malt is quiet dark with notes of toffee.
On cask at brews, brown color with dirty head, malt and balanced hop aroma,. Smooth taste with slight hops bitterness not too complex, ok.

Cask at Churchkey. Amber pour, bubbly head. Nose holds nice balanced blend of floral and citrus hops with some English biscuit and toffee malt. Similar flavor with further caramel. Creamy, low effervescence, Decent, not great.

Great cold weather beer, strong spice notes dominate, maybe a bit overdone imo, malty and pretty hoppy as well, toasted or burnt flavor coming in as well, all in all well done, sort of like a light scotch ale, me likey
Good beer.  Nice cold weather beer.  Taste like spice and bitterness with a nice balance of sweetness.
Malty sweet aroma.  Copper in color with an off-white head.  Strong  and malty, like an old ale.  Pretty good.
Clear amber color. Medium body with light head. Sweet malt, and carmel, aroma and taste. Modest hop bitterness is overshadowed by alcohol taste.
Bottle. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruitymalty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel finish with some bitterness.

Very viscous coming out of the bottle, almost scarily so.  The nose is malty but not convincing; not bad, just a little light.  Very deep, thick honey malt streak to start things off, yet the hops quickly tighten up the corners, keeping this bottle from turning into a breakfast pastry.  Thick feel yet restrained; six months on the shelf helps this beer.  Not bad in the late Spring.  (4/24/09)
Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks. Clear amber/brown - white head. Roasted, ok malty, sweetness, caramel, light bitterness, toasted, amber malts, dried fruits.

Bottle at Papsø.
Cloudy orange coloured with a small white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel and dried fruits with notes of hops and alcohol.
Fruity flavour of caramel, dried fruits, hops and grape fruits.
Dry hoppy finish.
Bottle at Papsø. Pours hazy amber with a mediumm off white head. The aroma is sweet malt, caramel, toasted malt and bread. The flavour is toasted malt, bread and dark fruit.
12 fl oz bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is mild fruity and slight caramelish. Caramelish, bitter and slight herbal hoppy. Bitter and dry malty finish.
Bottled. An amber beer with a thin off-white head. The aroma has malt, caramel, and hops. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and hops, leading to a bitter finish.

Bottled. Amber coloured. Small off white head. Aroma of flowers, citrus, some pine and caramel. Flavour of fruits, flowers, herbs, citrus, pine. Medium to full bodied. Caramelly bitterness in the end.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of Doodler. Pours a clear amber with a smal off-white head. Sweet caramel in the nose. Solid body, sweet dried dark fruits, some brown sugar, a phenollic touch. Some warming alcohol in the finish. 270411

Bottle.  Pours coppery red with a small tan head.  Aromas of citrus and floral hops, sugar, and some roasted malts.  The flavor is bitter pine and citrus, alcohol, and some brown sugar and cocoa.  Medium carbonation, and a touch warming.  Good.  [670]

Reviewed from notes.

Poured into a tulip. Pours a moderate copper color with a white head and a dose of lacing. The nose is fairly hoppy with some floral and earthy notes. Nice caramel notes. The taste is pretty good with a mild hoppiness. Feel is light and a tad bit harsh. Drinks fairly well and is a nice concept.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-09-2010

On tap at the Stanton Public House after Get Real NY.  Pours a clear ruby with a thin white head.  Sweet caramel, toast, spices.  Toast, medium bodied, more spice, malt and toast.  Caramel and spice, light bitterness and toast, spice and malt.

Poured into a snifter. Pours a light mahogany color, with an off-white/slightly tan head, that leaves decent lacing. Sweet aroma of prunes, figs and molasses. Tons of flavor up front, sweet immediately then the hops take over for the finish. Tastes of dried fruits with a floral garden finish. Warm and thick mouthfeel, mild carbonation. Very smooth for a 7.5% imperial ESB.

Clearish amber color with a medium off-white head. Malty, somewhat spicy aroma with some hop. Hop is more pronounced in the flavor with a nice malt balance and bitter finish. Ambitious brew that is pretty impressive.
Gold-amber pour with particulate floating throughout. Creamy white head. Aroma is light, citrus and flowers. Sweet flavor upfront with some hop at the finish. Overall very good.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Wegmans Leesburg 
The nose has a faintly floral, malty aspect to it.  There seems to be a nice English side to it, but perhaps a choice of hops that is different. The color is tea like with a slight haze and a very thin off white top.  The flavor starts off malty and fruity but quickly turns bitter.  Not necessarily a descriptive bitterness, just bitter.  Firm indeed.  Medium bodied with fairly aggressive carbonation leading to a crisp, firm, and dry bitterness.  Definitely different.  I can see the English heritage with a heavy bittering hand.

Bottle from Bruisin Ales. Pours dark ruddy copper with an off-white smear. It smells quite malty, almost with a chocolate note. Not getting hop. Or maybe something herby/floral. Full bodied. Rather fresh roast caramel. A little sweet, but theres a lot of hop. Floral mostly. A little thickish; a little sweetish; a lot hoppish. Yet it seems florally refreshing. Finishing very lightly sweet, but with a lot of hop. Unusual result.
Deep copper brown with a medium head. Both malty and hoppy. Strong and bitter. Some spice notes.

Great beer! smells of roasted malt, dates, orange peel hop.. Has nice redish/amber color with about a finger head. Taste is roasty malt  and bitter hop finish, with a bread, brown sugar, orange peel combination. Can taste a bit of the alchohol but not much. I really like this beer.

Pours hazy copper with a nice head that persists; no intensity to the aroma.  The liquor has a medium body with a nice bitter-sweet balance and a pleasing alcohol warmth that shines through.  A caramel malt profile with a long finish where the spicy hop lingers.   Got better as it warmed up (but then, what doesnt?).

A hazy reddish amber color with some orange and yellow highlights around the bottom and sides.  An off white head that was none too large nor did it have much retention.  Did leave patches of lace down the sides of the glass.  Very nice nose of some carmel malt, bread, biscuit and some nice flourishes of some grapefruit and orange citrus.  Seems very well balanced and really developes as the beer warms.  The taste brought forth some balanced plumes of bitterness from the grapefruit.  The dry malt of caramel and biscuit seems to fit together nicely with the citrus.  Small touches of alcohol do come throug in the flavor, but its nothing I cant handle.  Mouthfeel is medium.  Smooth and dry.  Nice bit of warmth from the alcohol.  Doesnt over do it with flavor on the palate, but does leave enough for me to savor for a bit.  This brew is really pretty good I think.  Very solid and well rounded.  Obviously this is a "Winter" beer, but I think I could enjoy this on occasion throughout the year.

dark harvest moon color with large eyeball carbs and beatiful lace. French toast and nutmeg aroma. slides down smooth. having trouble finding the goods. I might pair this one up with another Frontrunner.

Pours a rich amber color with an off-white head.  Aroma reveals a deep maltiness.  Taste starts with intense malt character and finishes with a strong bitterness mixed with lively alcohol content.  Cheers!

Poured a mostly clear dark orange with a fingers worth of head, which doesnt stick around too long. The aroma had some faint caramel. The taste is heavy on sweet bread, piney hops and even some faint orange peel. The bitterness certainly lingers on the aftertaste. The body is medium.

12 oz bottle. Pours a pristine orange-brown (like a great color for wood furniture) with tight beige head. The aroma is cotton candy and orange with some spicy hints and a little bit of English-style woody hops. The flavor is mild wood and a few fruity notes. Theres some earthy bitterness in the finish, but it remains fairly subdued. I get an occasional cotton candy hint. Not bad.

12oz bottle courtesy of my mom.  Pours a great clear deep amber color with a lasting one finger yellowish head.  Nice aroma of caramel, toffee, toast, spice, and grassy hops.  The flavor is very good, fairly rich for an ESB if its fair to call this one.  Deep caramel malts, toffee, biscuity toast, and good hop bitterness.  Nice dry and crisp finish.  Medium body with average carbonation.  Surprisingly refreshing after a long flight back east.  Im a fan.

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark orange-brwn color with a medium sized foamy tan head that lingered and produced good lacing. The aroma was faint  with notes of caramel, fruit and grass. The flavor was tangy with moderate caramel and light fruits. There was a sour and somewhat off middle that was a bit vegetal and fairly dry. The finish was long, tangy, dry and malty with some light vague fruits. Medium body with a bit of alcohol showing through. A couple of nice elements but overall rather disappointing.

Bottle.  Pours a deep reddish brown without much of a head.  Smells of cherry, wood, sugariness.   Really tastes similar to another beer I recently had.  Starts out with a good flavor but fades quickly.  Ok overall, but nothing exceptional.

aroma- bready, dates, toffee, caramel, raisin, roasted malt, bittersweet orange peel hop.  pours a woody red/amber with about 3/4 inch of head that recedes but doesnt go away, some lacing.  taste is roasty malt with a grassy earthy bitter hop finish, bread, brown sugar, orange peel, some alcohol.  palate is full bodied, some carbonation, smooth, bitter.

2010 12 oz. bottle poured to my favorite 1/2 pint taster with a clear, copper/amber hue, modest, tan, bubbly head foam that diminished rather quickly to a ring and film, and left a wave of lacing at the rim, followed by numerous spots below. The aroma was malty, caramel sweetness, secondary fruit, and spice hints. The flavor added a strong and full hop bitterness that lingered on the palate, followed by alcohol that gradually warmed after each sip. The carbonation was appropriately on the low side for a Strong Ale, and medium+ bodied. As we await our first snow of the season, this "winter warmer" was a welcome defroster.

This beer is dark amber in color with a tan head.  Nose is resin hops with some malt.  First taste is big bitters in your face.  Nice though.  Body is medium with average carbonation.  Finish is very nice lingering bitters.  a big beer for sure.

A clear amber pour with off-white head.  The malty aroma is filled with caramel and bread along with a touch of grassy hops.  The medium to full body has a slick texture.  The is taste pretty balanced with some sweetness up front and some bitterness in the finish.  You can very much feel the alcohol warmth.
Dark brown and clear. Malty and very alcoholic. Very thin for a "winter warmer" Not that great for the style.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Big boy thats plenty bite and bark.  I liked it but wouldnt write home about it, try this one.

12oz bottle pours a lively deep amber with medium to light khaki head.    Aroma is a very sweet malt and hop resin, some spice present.  Flavor is a carmel toffee malt but very well balanced with a hop bitterness.  Body is full almost creamy and slightly bitter, very palatable. Great beer

got to be as good as it gets for an esb. woody malt and bark with some hop for balance, perfume and a busy springy mouthfeel. full carbonation and foamy yet substantive mouthfeel with an amped up flavor and deceptively plain full aroma of beer. it is one hot esb.
Malty, earthy, nutty notes with some hops thrown in as well.  Taste the alcohol probably a bit more than I should.  Not too bad, but a bit underwhelming.

I missed this beer when it went off local shelves last year due to poor sales. I had originally lumped it into the same categories as Spatens Oktoberfest and Becks Oktoberfest for their same malt-heavy seasonality, but now realize the "Category 5 ale" needs to stand out on its own. Brew on, Clipper City!

poured from moderately priced 6er - Attractive dark amber ale that is silky smooth and backed with a considerable English hop presence--those English hops and malts are distinctive.  This is nicely balanced and enjoyed it more than I thought.  Heavy Seas = better than average heavy hitters.  Also, thanks for including freshness data Clipper City!

Poured a copper color.  Strong malty aroma, slightly nutty with a sense of stronger alcohol.  Subtle head.  Lacing on glass.  Lite sweetness along with med bitterness after the intial malty sweetness.  Med body, bitter finish.  Soft carbonation.  This was susprisingly pretty good- I thought this was going to taste pretty malty after smelling it.  But the hops kicked in and made a balanced bitter flavor.  Would try again.

sample from the bottle at the Decatur Beer Festival on 10/16/10.  deep orange pour with a thin white head.  malt nose with sweet notes.  medium body with caramel and sweet malts.  finishes somewhat bland with thin layers of caramel and light fruit.

Lucent amber, thin white head, medium body, medium carbonation.

Aroma: bright citrusy leafy aroma hops, catamel malt, some breadyness.

Taste: lots of leafy bittering hops, some bready caramel malt, a note of bright citrusy late hops, just a hint of the rather subdued alcohol.

A nice hoppy and fruity ale with a subdued caramel malt background.

Pours medium brown and transparent with a little bit of off-white head. Nose is mostly a generic malty sweetness with just a hint of hops. Flavor is fairly weak but pleasant; a brown sugary and apple-like malt is balanced by moderate at best bittering hops. Finish is slightly sticky. It goes down easy but theres nothing unique or especially great here.
A clear dark orange/red pour with foamy white head. Deep malty scent with a hint of booze. Taste is malty with a bitter bready finish.

2008 Bottle. Pretty dark brown with orange tints and a low, fine head.  Nicely fragrant, with English and American hops still smelling nice after the time. Orange, tobacco, caramel. Appetizing. Flavorful malts, with chocolate and caramel, plus nice hops. Tobacco, grass, earth, plus a very bitter finish. Wow. Tastes fresh. Nice, verging on an old ale by now, though completely un-oxidized. Mellow and smooth, and very bitter. Would like to try it fresh to get those hops.

12oz bottle.   Pours dark amber with a medium thin beige head and light lacing.  Sharp hoppy aroma of grapefruit and pine.  Floral hop flavors that leave a slick hop oil coating with sweet and subdued malts that come through shortly before the aftertaste hits with hops and delicious bitterness.  Definitly hoppy, but nicely balanced.

Pours an orangey (black and orangey?) copper with a thin but persistent ivory head. Some light lacing.

Lots of big citrusy hops in the nose buoyed by bready malt aromas.

The first sips reveal big hops but this beer is not just a hops delivery vehicle. Although it does that quite well. Its strangely balanced with the sweet and considerable bready malt profile. Bitter herbal and citrusy hops dominate the finish and aftertaste. Their website says they use American and English hops and I believe it. Not sure Ive ever tasted this combination of hops working in such balance before.

First thing I noticed was the extremely full body.  This is one heavily creamy brew...so smooth and so substantial.  The taste is almost as great, with just a little bit of dirt in the aftertaste that lingers.  Otherwise, it has a great transition from sweet and mellow at first to bitter and a little sour on the back of your tongue.  You cant really notice the alcohol too much with all else going on.    Appearance is okay...could use more head, but who couldnt?  Aroma is...a little weird, very biscuity with some figs maybe? i cant put my finger on the aroma, but its sweet, complex and not too strong.  Overall, I think I may have found my "go to" ESB.   Awesome.

Bottle:  Poured an orangish color with a nice head.  The aroma was sweet malts and caramel.  The flavor was caramel, sweet malts, some vanilla, and a nice bitter finish.  Overall, a beer worth searching out.

Pours attractive orange brown with a halo of a cream colored head. Nose is crystal and caramel malts with some fruit influence as well. Same in the flavor with an earthy and slight spicy addition. Subtle but lasting bitter finish.

12 fl oz bottle from Cs Farm Market, served cool in a Scotch Irish taster glass. 
App.:  Clear deep amber with a fairly nice orange-tan foam.
  
Aroma:  Some nice brown sugar, toffee, bready, biscuity malts, fairly fruity with berries and some dark dried fruits coming through, the malts veer into med-roasted coffee, theres an earth, dank, slightly soapy and floral hop note, a touch of booze, wisps of esters, pretty nice nose!
  
Palate:  Medium body, moderate effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Much like the the nose with lots of tasty, crunchy, baked malt flavours seasoned with earthy, woody, slightly citrusy/soapy/floral hops, hints of esters and a wee hint of booze; dry with fairly good bitterness and a mainly crunchy malt finish. 

Geez, I like it.  An American, over-the-top approach to non-American styles can work beautifully, at least for my tastes.

It pours slightly hazy with a beautiful sunset red color. Both the aroma and flavor are that of sweet malts balanced perfectly with smooth hops. The head is small, but that seens normal to me on on ESB. Very smooth for 7.3%.

Bottle. Small beige head with poor retention, transparent body, slow rising carbonation, minimal lacing, and an orange hue. The aroma is somewhat weak for the style - malty, caramel, earthy, and bitter hops. The flavor mimicked the aroma; however, the taste is very nice. Mouthfeel is tingly and this is a medium bodied beer. This is a very easy to drink beer, not too bitter tasting, worthy of a try, and a beer I would drink again.

Nice crystal clear copper color with a thin white head. Strong malt aroma. Somewhat nutty with a caramel sweetness. Flavor is also pretty malty but is quickly overpowered by a hoppy bitter finish. Slightly over-carbonated for an ESB. Perhaps thats the "imperial" part.

12 oz bottle: Upfront malt with some funky maybe Saaz or Hellertau hop aroma.  After a few seconds the hops take over and all I smell is funky hops, which isnt necessarily a bad thing.  Somewhat funky. Appearance is a deep rich amber color with a thin white head that doesnt stick around for long.  Taste is malt upfront with caramel, bread, candied sugar, and the hops are really subdued in the taste overall.  Palate is nicely carbonated, bubbly, with an aftertaste of hop and raw malt.  Overall, Really decent brew in my honest opinion.  Cheers!

Draft: Weak aroma of cherries and cinnamon.  Clear red with a medium yellow head, good lacing. Flavor is of cherries, strawberries. Light cinnamon finish. A bit perfumey and very fruity. Alcohol evident.

12 oz bottle.  Dark amber pour with a thin off white head.  Aroma of roasted malt and peppery hops.  Bitter taste that hides the ABV consisting of roasted malt, some barnyard earthy flavors and faint spices.  Lasting finish.

Thanks JoeMcPhee for the bottle. Aroma of malt, slight hint of syrup. amber in colour with a thin white lace. Low carbonation. Great texture, quite silky with a good body. Seems quite and earthy flavour, malt with a sharp hop bitterness. Very nice solid ESB.

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Amber color, almost two finger light tan head, but doesnt retain much, some spotty lacing.  Aroma is caramel malts, then some fruit, green raisins, banana, into some citrus/pine hops.  Flavor is sweet caramel malts, some fruit, bread, with a somewhat bitter, hoppy finish.  Mouthfeel is slick, moderate fullness, medium carbonation.  I enjoyed this one, but have had very few ESBs to compare it to.

Small frothy white head pours to a sparkling ruby body. Burnt straw. Harsh hops of pine,spruce, and grapefruit that die out to a very long lasting bitter in your mouth. It was a good example of an Imperial ESB. Im glad to see breweries are keeping esbs alive.

On cask at redlight. Pours a cloudy amber color topped by a small head of white foam that receds quickly to a thin film. The aroma is pretty hoppy with citrus and pine hops atop a sweet caramel malt base. The flavor follows with the fresh pine and citrus hops coming forward along with ample amount of caramel malt to sweeten up the bitterness. This was really tasty fresh from the cask. Medium bodied, smooth and very to drink. This makes for a really nice cask conditioned beer.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2012 Location/Date:Draft at Gillys, January 17th, 2012.
Appearance:Pours a dark brown.
Aroma: Aroma is of caramel and light malt.
Taste: Medium bitterness, strong malt, some sweetness.
Palate:Palate is light medium, lingering aftertaste.
Summary: A solid beer to get through the winter, although if Im going to 7.5% for a beer Id probably have something else.


 Old rating: Bottle drank on 2009 CFB NC night.  Solid hop aroma, decent bitterness.  not a memorable strong ale.

What a nice beer! Shared this tonight with my buddy Brandon. A purchase of mine from my trip out east a month ago. Poured a dark mahogany with a fairly large fluffhead. Aroma is beautiful. Nose is hoppy with some alcohol fumes mixed in with raisins and earth. Taste is hoppy firm, and full on the palate. A really chewy delectable beer with lots of flavour. Smoke, tannin and plum.

Slight caramel aroma with a little hint of Sweet Tarts.  Bitter on the tongue, with a decent malt background.  A bit watery for an extreme beer, the mouth feel could be fuller.  Not bad, but not special.
Pours hazy orange amber with a thin off-white head. Aroma is outdated hops and caramel. Taste is slightly off, bottle is definitely past date. Medium body, funky finish, need to rerate.
tap @ RnH - A very fresh tasting beer. Sweet caramel and piney hops. Ends nice and bitter.
Pours dark copper color with off white head. Biscuit malt aroma. Caramel malt flavor with some fruitiness and moderate hop bitterness. Medium body with average carbonation.
Bright amber colorwith a minimal off white head.  Aroma is dark bread dough.  Nice sweet roasted malt taste; buttery caramel and brown sugar as well.  Decent hop bite at the close.  Very good.

12 ounce bottle from a local beer store in WashPA, slim pickings after Christmas, so I picked up a Clipper City variety case. Pours a deep mahogany color with a large white head. A sweet nose of caramel, light hops. The flavor is nice; toasted malts, lots of English fruity hops, loads of caramel. Decent.

12 ounce bottle - $1.79 at Hop City in Atlanta, Georgia. Purchase Before: February 2010.

Appearance: Pours out a translucent, darkened amber body with a finger-high, off-white head. Very thin, very sheer lacing on the way down.

Smell: Well-toasted malts seasoned with sugar and spice and a small dash of dried citrus peels, with just hint of alcohol in the background.

Taste: Malt profile tasting of deeply toasted and subsequently crushed bread crusts sweetened with a generous mixture of both brown sugar and common, ordinary, everyday table sugar. Slight fruitiness. Earthy, zesty, citrusy hop profile with a medium-high bitterness. The initial sweet, sugary quality comes straight back into the taste alongside the persistent bitterness for a bittersweet, lightly crisp finish at the end.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium-plus carbonation.

Drinkability: Its alright, I suppose. Its sweet, its got ample bitterness, and alcohol (though thankfully not anymore than it does). Personally, Ive never been overly enamored with the Heavy Seas line-up, but you could certainly do alot worse than this.

Comes out of the tap a warm translucent coppery amber with a fine, coppery-tan head Aroma is strong, spicy, malty and slightly hoppy. Flavor is rich, malty and spicy with an undertone of hops that is only slightly bitter. Texture is sharp, lively, sassy and tingly and leaves a hoppy-bitter and spicy finish.

Bottle from Sams.  Pours clear amber-red with small light beige head. Coaxes up a lovely head when swirled. Nose of bitter hops and generous malts, including some caramel and vanilla notes. Maybe mild spice, but nothing definite going on there.  Similar taste, but huge bitterness, especially on the finish.  Interesting attempt, but seems like it would be better if they didnt go for "imperial" with this one.

(12 ounce bottle - half pint glass)  pours an orange liquid that leads to little head and very little lacing.  Aroma is slightly sour and malty.  Taste has notes of molasses and toffee, it is also sour.  Medium bodied, slightly creamy texture, and soft carbonation.
Amber/brown colored pour with off-white head. Lots of malt sweetness and citrus hops. Finishes clean, very drinkable ESB.

12 ounce bottle enjoyed on Thanksgiving Day out of a Heavy Seas variety pack. This poured a light amber color with a one finger width white head that disappeared very quickly. The aroma consisted of some light hops, malt, and a bit of dark fruit. The taste was along the same lines with a bit more of the hops and malt coming through. This reminded me a bit of a light IPA. Finished smooth and was easy to drink. Overall, I was surprised by this one... I was not expecting much.

On tap in USA. A reddish brown with a tan head that quickly diminished. Aroma of spices, citrus, hops, and a light caramel background. The flavor found hops, grass, caramel, and spices. Medium body with a light bitterness. Not bad.
From a bottle poured amber with a fair amount of head. Nice hoppy flavor with a kinging finish.

Pour is one of the best amber colored beers I have ever seen. thin head with plenty of bubbling up the middle of the glass. aroma was malt and citrus hops. Taste was once again hoppy and bitter. the palate had some nice crispness fromt he carbination. Well hidden alcohol. must try more from heavy seas.

Shared with my brother on Thanksgiving since Clipper City is one of his favorite breweries - and mine.  This offering is another solid brew from them.  Aroma of malt, caramel and faint hops.  Smooth, balanced malty taste with caramel, doughy bread, faint floral hops and a little spice finish.  The mouthfeel on this ale was full and very smooth - the alcohol was not detected at all in this one.

Bottle.  Pours dark reddish-brown with a small off-white head.  Aroma is of bittering hops and caramel malt.  Flavor is hoppy with a slight amount of malt, and has an even more hoppy and bitter finish.  Interesting beer as Ive not had anything quite like it, and a very good beer as well.
This one poured a darker ruby red color with an off white head. Aroma was light plums, toffee and some caramel malt. Flavor was toasted, medium maltiness but not much else going on.

Freshly tapped cask @ redlight redlight. Whoo, the hops on the nose of this were super fresh, grassy fresh, hints of citrus. Some malt and a bit of British-style fruity yeast esters. Sheets of lacing all down the glass, coppery body. Flavor is malt some caramel, grassy hops nice bitterness. Light mouthfeel, drinks like a smaller beer, probably from the cask? I must never get Clipper City beers fresh, cause fresh this was great.

355mL into Sam Adams mad awesome glass. Nothing gives me more pleasure than enjoying almost every beer save for Sam Adams in their kick-ass glass. Pours a deep, orange-tinted amber with a thin, tan head that has little retention and leaves no lacing. Aroma is blueberries, apple pie, peach cobbler. Taste is malty, biscuity, with lots of berries. Major resiny hop bitterness in the finish. Alcohol is nicely hidden. Yum.

cask @ redlight redlight.  Solid malt nose with good hop flavor, caramel notes and citrusy hops.  Pours caramelly red amber with a very thick fluffy white head.  Caramelly malts with spicy citrus hops, super fresh tasting.  A wonderful cask session beer!
Cask at redlight.  Cloudy amber.  Nice hoppy aroma.  Drinks real nice and smooth.  I like this brew, dude.

Pours reddish amber with thick, off-white head. Light aroma of yeast, caramel, roasted nuts and molasses. Light sweetness, malty, balanced with medium bitterness and sourness; long finish of roasted nuts; oily/creamy mouthfeel.

21oz Bottle from TW. Reddish hue with a thin lacing. Light roasted malt in aroma along with English hops. Nice body, medium and a bit creamy. Bitter aftertaste and the English malt flavor stays with you. Nice in this respect. A bit sweeter and a bit fruity half way through. This is a pretty decent brew.

text: Enjoyed on tap in a nonic glass.  The beer pours a deep dark amber to medium-dark brown color, with a slightly off-white head.  The aroma is of American hops initially, before fading to some caramelly malt notes.  The palate is accentuated by medium-low carbonation, and shows a nice bitterness at first, followed by a malt character that is at once sweet and toffee-like.  The finish is slightly fruity, evidencing a slight ester profile of English yeast.  The beer is easily quaffable, and belies its mid-high alcohol content.  Overall, a nicely crafted and executed winter warmer.

Pours amber with a light tan head.  Aroma is earthy hops with a touch of caramel in the background.  Flavor is a nice balance of caramel malt and earthy, spicy, slightly citrusy hop with a nice bitter finish.  Pretty good.
Bottle to glass.  Nice clear brown color.  Sweet malty aroma. Has a bit of floating matter throughout. has a nice hoppy flavor and a pleasant suprise.

Received a 12-oz bottle via trade with kmweaver. Pours a semi-hazy reddish amber with a thin off-white film coating on top. Aroma of caramel, roasted nuts, citrus and a hint of vegetable. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonated, flavors of caramel malt, some vanilla and citrus. Finish is semi-sweet with a caramel and yeast aftertaste that slowly disappears.

Pours deep amber into an English pint. Off-white conglomerate head with excellent retention leaves spotted sheets as it slowly recedes. Orange citrus aromas. Syrupy yet dry upfront with yeast and caramel.  Lasting bitter finish.
Nice aroma has a bit of earthy hops with hints of dry leaves.  Flavor is not super complex  malt up front with the hoppy finish.  Not bad.

Bottle as part of a tasting at Catskeller.  Pours clear amber with a small beige head.  Aroma of sweet caramel malts, toast, and hops with some booziness.  Warming alcohol, bitter hops, and sweet caramel malts make up the flavor of this beer, which has nice balance.  Light bodied, and lives up to its "warmer" title.  Still, the aroma didnt do a whole lot and I wasnt crazy about the taste of this one.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2010 Cask at Churchkey. Cloudy amber with chunks and floaties, medium light tan bubbles, just around the edge of the glass. Aroma of bread and caramel. Nicely hopped but with a good malt balance. Taste has a few splinters of oak, very subtle. Longish bitter finish. Nice enough.

A truly excellent looking beer in the glass: dark amber color, dense white head.  Matched with the malted hops aroma a had high hopes for this beer well before the first sip.  The taste was remarkable, full bodies and complex, but not overly dry or bitter.  In fact it reminded me a little of fine cognac.  at the end I was ready to lick out the glass.  Cheers.

12 oz. bottle from Macs on West Peachtree. Nice dark brown transparent apperance. NIce fluffy head that fades away rather slowly. Nice looking beer I must say. Fairly well balanced in terms of aroma. Lots of low scores on the aroma? A nice balanced sweet malt and hop aroma. Very sweet aroma, almost a fruity sweet aroma. The flavor is decent. Sweet malt and a decent hop flavor. Beer is not exceptionally smooth. Hop flavor fades away rather quickly. A decent ESB with some good hop and malt flavors, but nothing that stands out really.

Poured to a brownish orange with medium off-white head and some lacing. Nose was very hard to detect and the mouthfeel was slightly on the thin side. Taste tried to bring out some caramel hints, as well as a touch of hoppy fruit, but didnt exceed well. At 7.3% abv, I would have expected either a whiff or taste of alcohol, but got neither. Not surprisingly, finish was somewhat on the short and watery side.

Have realoly enjoyed the others Ive had from Clipper City...this one just missed the mark slightly.

Pours a dark, slightly hazy golden amber/chestnut brown color with a thin fizzy yellow head that quickly fades. Not much in the way of lacing.

Bland aroma with some slightly roasted malt notes, subtle hops and sweet alcohol.

Nicely balanced medium body with some caramel malt and hazelnut countering a bitter earthy hop presence. The hop bitterness is pretty tame and not too overpowering but lasts throughout. The ABV is pretty well masked with only some slight alcohol warmth.

This beer was dark orange, and decent looking. Smelled like nothing and tasted weird. I guess I dont understand the point of an imperial ESB, why not just make a good ESB? Why does everything have to be "Imperial"? It tasted alcoholic and sweet. This beer was not my bag.

Serving type: bottle

A pale blush red. Large foamy head. Hazy with visible specks of sediment. Thick creamy lace. Great.

Malts sweetly toasted caramel, with hints of sweet berries. Light mocha. Grassy, flowery hop presence. A little sweeter than expected but nice.

Sweet cherry liqueur in the taste. The malts come in more sweet in the taste. Caramel and mocha give a balance. Sharp spicy hop, earthy and rustic. Leafy.

Creamy and rather thick feel. A tiny burn at the swallow. A good, slightly unbalanced drink. Very drinkable but sweeter than it could be.

Gazing at my Winter Storm from Clipper City Brewings Heavy Seas line reminds me that the next season of Deadliest Catch should be starting soon. Every episode I watch almost makes me want to brave those very seas. Almost. I am far flung from the wintry perils of the Bering Seas, but over the years I have seen my fair share of rough and tumble seas. Being at the mercy of Mother Natures majestic and deadly beauty is a very sobering reminder of our place in the world.


Glistening mahogany, as if someone had just taken a fresh shine to it, shimmers in the light while dark ruby highlights are reflected in her depths. A small puffy head fades quickly into a ringlet, but some stirring of her seas tosses about scattered clumps of frothy lace while her nose is carried upward for my enjoyment. Warm, sweet, and moist cinnamon apples fresh from the oven seduce while plums, prunes, and raisins add a bit of meat to her body. Lemon and pink grapefruit gives her a playful bite while rum-soaked breads, licorice, vanilla, and wood receive a small helping of maple syrup. A plethora of wintery delights indeed. The rich bready notes soaked in rum and spices is ready and waiting for me as I dive into her inviting depths. Dry winter spices abound, almost like a dry rub on top of my tongue, a generous helping to truly soak in all those flavors. Sweet maple syrup and brown sugar provides a bit of a sweeter undercurrent while rummy warmth lingers long into her finish and my breath. The lemon and pink grapefruit zest nips at the back of my throat after each quaff, and then retreats to let moist dessert breads, rum, and moist plums, prunes, and raisins bring out more maple and brown sugar. This all may sound a bit heavy and cloying, but her mouthfeel and palate is rather bright and refreshingly brisk. Everything is tied together perfectly and as my Winter Storm subsides, I am left pleasantly soaked, but the better for it.


I am reminded a bit of Samuel Smiths Winter Welcome Ale because it too is clean, crisp, and refreshing, just like the Winter Storm from Clipper City Brewing. Weight, body, and mouthfeel aside, she is every bit as wintry as her name suggests, with all the spices, sugars, fruits, breads and rum a person requires to keep their spirits afloat and warm during those chilly months. A brew well-done; not great, but good.

Pours a lacing beige head and a ruby-amber body with particulates.  Smells of mellow hops, caramel, and a little metallic.  Flavor is caramel, biscuit, mellow citrus hops.  Finish has a nice bitterness and is somewhat floral.

Bottle split with curly and barrios at woodys.  Pours a near clear burnt orange with thin wispy light tan head.  Nose is sweetly floral, with an old mustiness to it, and some caramel.  Tastes like old celery hops with some faded spiciness and a distinct metallic penny finish.  At least 6 months past the expiration date, this still isnt all that bad.  Would love to try this again fresh.

Pours a nearly clear mahogany with a long lasting head. Nose is Nutty and caramel laden with some citrus flavors peaking through, intriguing. Flavor is malty up front with nice lingering toasted nut and deep caramel quite a hoppy finish with decent bitterness. Though they claim to have used English hops they seem more like american hops. I got some definite citrus flavors not typical of many english hops. Still a very very solid ESB.

Source:  2006, 12 oz bottle.  Dont remember where I purchased it. Glass: North Coast Snifter. Appearance: Ruddy brown/orange color with no noticeable head.  Aroma:  At this point no hops exist.  Sweet malt, caramel and toffee are the dominant notes. Flavor: Solid malty background with a decent bitter finish.  Not much complexity, but generally enjoyable to drink. Palate:  Medium/full body with soft/no carbonation.Overall:  Good beer.  Has held up to the years well.  Would like to try some fresh though.
good taste if you like hoppy beers.  Dark in color and a strong beer too.  Would buy again....
Tap @ winter brew fest in mount holly. Although many beers had been tasted this beer had a flavor that stuck out. Otherwise no notes to put down.

[1889-20081206] Cask. Toasted hoppy yeast aroma. Clear, dark red body with quick off-white bubbles. Boozy heavy sweet yeast flavour has lots of toasted grains throughout. Medium-full body. Warming.
(@ Coles; Buffalo, NY)

The aroma & taste line up almost exactly: a mix of flavors built around licorice and hops. The maltiness of Winter Storm in combination with the candy makes this feel like a dessert. Mouthfeel is good, but the flavors are not subtle in any sense of the word, and that gives this a fakeness to me. Its hard to explain. I feel like Im opening a box of crayons and seeing a row of color-coded flavors (Pie Brown and Sugary Red!) presented in order. If youre looking for a "winter warmer," Id recommend the Weyerbacher Fireside over this.

[Bottle] Pours reddish-amber with a small beige head. The aroma is decent with a good amount of hops, a sort of nuttiness, and caramel. Pretty good. The taste has some noticeable alcohol, along with a lot of malt, and some hops, although the bitterness is quite restrained. Good mouthfeel, smooth, with a medium-long finish. A solid beer that is easy to drink and well made.
Overall Impression: This was a nice beer, dont have the particulars in front of me, but heres the ranking for when I tried it...

Pretty good. Not overpowering for a strong ale, but somewhat complex. Surprisingly light and drinkable. Well balanced, fortunately not too sweet. Light carbonation and small head. A little bit of candy like flavor. No alcohol. Weak finish.
Bottle from Villa, Storrs, CT. Amber color with a nice hop/malt mix. A good ol reliable that isnt to harsh with the ABV.
12 oz. bottle.Lacking in the aroma area, this beer just doesnt do it for me. The taste is almost watered-down. Flavors of sweet malt but then no finish. Light-hop flavors. Just didnt do it for me.

bottle poured an amber in color with some suspended sediment and a thin off white head. aroma has sweet caramel, floral hops, fruit, and plenty of malt. mouth feel is light and the carbonation average. flavor has a nice malted core, well hopped, good bitterness, and citrus hints. fairly hefty but well balanced. kept me interested through the glass.

Pours a nice crisp dark copper with a very thin though long lasting off white head. Aroma is lots of caramel, toffee, toast, grain, floral and citrus hops, a touch of pine and alcohol. A fine start to the beer. Flavor is sweet malt, a little toast, alcohol, a little tangy fruit, maple leaf. Finish is pretty uneventfull, sort of fruity, burnt sugar and slight bitterness, the beer kind of fades with very little change in flavor or depth. Palate is thin and oily then dry. I am not sure I have ever had anything billed as an Impy ESB, but this stuff is confusing, sort of a highly hopped Barleywine Light. I think it would go fantastically with a greasy pulled pork sandwich or 3 though.

20090214  12oz bottle from Spirits RB.  BBF Mar 09.  Dark amber, mostly clear, with small but lingering beige head presenting little foamy islands and soapy suds of streaky lace.  Aroma is lightly floral, caramel, earl grey tea.  Sweet stuff, full and malty, earthy tea and leaf flavors, light citrus and teaberry.  Fairly vigorous carbonation helps tame the otherwise hefty body.  Finish has a mild hop bite, mineral and herb.  Eh, its okay stuff.  Probably a tick better when fresh, but its only a couple months old.

(Bottle (best before 3/09) from McKean and Charles) Basically pass...Pours reddish amber with just a bit of biege head. Aroma of cotton candy, maybe a hint of fruit, some pine. Mouthfeel fairly loose and watery, relatively speaking. A bit sticky in finish. Some very light spotty lacing along with a light syrupy film. Flavor is just sort of candyish sweet, light fruit (pineapple), a touch of pine in finish. A little hot. Kind of a crossover between a barleywine and a big IPA that never develops much of a flavor profile.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2011 Amber Brown with amodest head from a bottle, Nice lacing  Modest aroma, big mouth feel with roasted malt, and caramel but a bit to much bitter iron blood aftertaste.  It mellows Ok but not smooth
2011 on tap, dark tan nice head and lacing, alcoholic and just a tad thin.
Balanced hoppy ale moderate floral taste with a creamy mouth feel and a slightly bitter finish.
Amber pour with a small white head. Aroma is of hops. Very nicely bitter flavor. Very crisp and clean finish.

(12oz bottle) Courtesy of Oakes. Pours a dissipating, white head with a copper body. This has that same strange aroma as the loose cannon - mild malt, bready. Decent hops I guess but overall this isnt terribly overwhelming. 6/3/7/3/14

Smells of bitter and slightly sour hops, quite strong. Taste is heavy bitter hops, like an esb, with some sour notes as well with a decent malt back. Very nice well-rounded ale that hides the 7%+ alcohol very well

12 ounce bottle from Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a clear copper color with a large head. Good head retention and poor lacing. Aroma is nutty with caramel malts and some fruity notes. Taste is grainy with caramel and bitter hops. Medium bodied.

Bottle.  Pours a reddish brown with a little bit of a bubbly film on the surface.  Aromas are sweet:  malt and fruit (apples and oranges).  Flavor is just plain heavy in all areas... alcohol, malt and hops all come through as overbearing at different points and the flavors dont blend together well enough for my tastebuds to get really excited.  This is kind of an ongoing complaint I have with the Heavy Seas beers.  Still, this one is better than most I have had by them.
